abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Enlargement of the endolymphatic sac, duct, and vestibular aqueduct (EVA) is the most common inner ear malformation identified in patients with sensorineural hearing loss. EVA is associated with pathogenic variants in <jats:italic>SLC26A4.</jats:italic> However, in European–Caucasian populations, about 50% of patients with EVA carry no pathogenic alleles of <jats:italic>SLC26A4</jats:italic>. We tested for the presence of variants in <jats:italic>CHD7</jats:italic>, a gene known to be associated with CHARGE syndrome, Kallmann syndrome, and hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, in a cohort of 34 families with EVA subjects without pathogenic alleles of <jats:italic>SLC26A4</jats:italic>. In two families, NM_017780.4: c.3553A > G [p.(Met1185Val)] and c.5390G > C [p.(Gly1797Ala)] were detected as monoallelic <jats:italic>CHD7</jats:italic> variants in patients with EVA. At least one subject from each family had additional signs or potential signs of CHARGE syndrome but did not meet diagnostic criteria for CHARGE. In silico modeling of these two missense substitutions predicted detrimental effects upon CHD7 protein structure. Consistent with a role of CHD7 in this tissue, <jats:italic>Chd7</jats:italic> transcript and protein were detected in all epithelial cells of the endolymphatic duct and sac of the developing mouse inner ear. These results suggest that some <jats:italic>CHD7</jats:italic> variants can cause nonsyndromic hearing loss and EVA. <jats:italic>CHD7</jats:italic> should be included in DNA sequence analyses to detect pathogenic variants in EVA patients. <jats:italic>Chd7</jats:italic> expression and mutant phenotype data in mice suggest that CHD7 contributes to the formation or function of the endolymphatic sac and duct.</jats:p>

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: Authors declare no conflict of interest.

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: Patients. This study (01-DC-0228) was approved by the Combined Neuroscience Institutional Review Board at the National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, Maryland, USA. All adult subjects provided written informed consent and minor subjects provided assent. Animals. All animal experiments and procedures were performed according to protocols approved by the joint Animal Care and Use Committee of the National Institute of Neurological Diseases and Stroke and the National Institute on Deafness and Other Communication Disorders (#1264).

funder.name: National Institute on Deafness and Other Communication Disorders

title: CHD7 variants associated with hearing loss and enlargement of the vestibular aqueduct
